comments.commentBody: Anybody who believes that the Republican agenda is what the Founding Fathers intended can call me, I have some real estate in Florida  to sell you.
Governor Walker can be the new face of the 'Russian Republican Party'.  Be strong, comrade.
@organic farmer:  THANK YOU!  I believe you've gotten to the heart of this issue with great clarity.  Well said!

"..a meaningless job which gums up our lives and produces absolutely, positively, unequivocally ZERO."

Though you don't name a single job, not one, ZERO.

By the way: 70% of the federal budget goes to pay FEDERAL entitlements like social security, which goes to average Americans. Republicans just want to eliminate as much of that as they can--by "returning" power to the states, you know...like it used to be, before "the liberals" ruined everything.

"{Y]ou have your own on-the-spot, individualized benefits program, with a bit of means-testing, mental health and character assessment, and criminal-background check — to the extent that any of this is possible from a second or two of looking someone up and down."

That's right.

Obviously, Francis doesn't slog back and forth to work on the IND and Lexington Avenue lines.
Suppression of legitimate free speech?  Is that Walker advocates?

Rigghhht.   Let's   give  an  alcoholic   some   money   to  buy   alcohol  with.   Did   the   pope   ever   consider   the   fact  that   a   homeless   person   might   not   be   in  that    state   if   he   didn't   abuse   alcohol  or  drugs?   Yes,  yes,  I  know.    Some   homeless   people   are   mentally  ill.  But  maybe   he   isn't.  I'd   be  homeless   too   if  I  hadn't  stayed  in  school,   learned  a  profession  in   the   medical   field   and   worked   for   40 plus   years.  Duh !

Then hand the person a sandwich.
You can still find a way to be compassionate. I also went through medical school. Along the way I had one year of living extremely frugally. It was difficult, and I didn't ask for assistance.Yet I always had that safety net of parents, friends, and family I could have called on if it had come down to it. I was blessed with good physical and mental health, and a genetic resistance to addiction. That year hard as it was was nothing compared to what many people have to endure, because I had the hope and expectation that it would end and I would move on to a better phase.
You seem to forget that the homeless and addicted have often lost hope. They lack that go-to safety net that you and I had. You should be thankful for your blessings, and a bit less judgmental of those that don't have them.
Exactly. Be prepared for a litany of condemnation from the morally superior and utterly clueless core readership of the NY Times.

Here's a question that, perhaps, goes to the root of the issue:

Without the judgement of those with whom one interacts, is it reasonable to assume, or even presume, that the trajectory of another's live will change?

Intervention is a valid method of drawing the attention of "the one being judged" to the facts surrounding his condition and providing options for the "accused" to change and better his lot.

These interventions can be done through large gatherings of concerned family and friends, or can be done with and indivual going out of his way with a helping hand.

Let me rephrase your implied question, if I may:

Is it "Christian" to allow a person to continue to abuse himself without any interference from others?

I suspect that "judging" would be far less a sin, if a sin at all, than in allowing a person to commit suicide by the fluid ounce or powder dose.

No one has asked anyone here to sell their possessions and give the proceeds to the poor.

However, if you should choose to do so.......some say that there is a kingdom that awaits you.

When asked "Who is my neighbor?" Jesus answered with the story of The Good Samaritan.  In that story, there are no qualifications as to who the person in need was.  It was just help anyone you see in need.  Matthew 25:31-45 tells essentially the same story.  Whatever you do for the least of these you do for Me is what Jesus said.  Jesus also said "Judge not least you be judged."  It is obvious that Pope Francis is very familiar with The Gospel of Jesus and lives it out.  He surely will hear "Well done thy good and faithful servant" someday.

Gov. Walker, I will believe you want to return power to the states only if the states are conservative. What would you do with a state that tried to ban a pesticide, require GMO labeling, ban assault rifles, or help unions? You would shut them down instantly. That's been the pattern with Republicans. Are you sincere this time, or are you a hypocrite as usual?

'Put-up or shut-up' is also good advice for Democrats. You didn't bother to vote. Maybe you were lazy. Maybe Hillary wasn't perfect enough for you. Congressional elections and state and local elections aren't important enough to merit your attention. Either way, now you've got this. Live with it.
It is amazing that, once again, a person must be reminded that 3 million more people voted for Hillary than for the other person.

Or -- which is what we are all worried about -- die from it.  This is not a sports match where our team lost!  The lives and prosperity of Americans and the future health of the world are what is at stake!
Forget it. The Dems wil never get it. They abandoned FDR and JFK long before the Republicans embraced Russia.

Walker, you are preaching the same old Republican mantra-if you don't agree with me you are my enemy, you are evil, and you are non-patriotic.  You dismantled Union worker rights in your State to help the big corporations.

State control has always been a great concept, but it's when the states do a lousy job the feds need to step in and create balance...and justice.  I'm not really concerned about party....just fairness and justice.  Don't let your ideology get in your way of creating what's right for people.  When you see so much partisanship voting in Washington on legislation...well it shows little care about what's best for the country and people.  Just sayin'..........
Sorry, anti-vaxers are everywhere, far too many among Democrats too. This foolishness is not partisan.

Americans wake up and throw these anti-society/retrograde leaning people called Republicans out of office.

Today it is not a question of competing methods and means to achieve a better World, where the best person for the job, R or D, could and should win our vote.

No today the current Rs have NOT the same framework most of us have. They are inescapably driven by the ideologies dominating their structure to be combative, revisionist, reactionary, retrograde, and anti-society.

They must ignore the ecology of all things – the intertwining of all things animate and inanimate.

Their World View dictates that they have a level of antiscience/anti-fact-ism, tribalism, selfishness, chosen-people-ism, zero-sum-ism, cynicism, and anti-big-picture-ism long ago cast off by the majority of the modern successful World.

Their war against Universal Healthcare despicable. Their war with Environment Protection more egregious.

Couching their battles cleverly they ignore actual implementations and the scientific whys, wherefores, and net positive consequences. Example: “rollback the CO2 emission tailpipe standards before we bankrupt the auto-industry!”

Fact: meeting standards cost $15B/year in an ~$190B/year PROFIT auto industry; it's not bankrupting; other Companies will and ARE stepping up to the challenge.

Why encourage American mediocrity while contributing to a less viable environment?

Oh right! it fits the faux populous ideology du jour and it jabs at ex-President O!

"How dare voters express anger?" - seems to be Walker's message.

Wasn't that the very message of the Declaration of Independence?

The "Republican agenda" of returning political authority to the States is well underway.  In fact, it's not stopping at the state lines, but going straight to the people who will be turning them out in coming elections.

We were given a choice. It was Hillary who won the popular vote. Maybe these protests are to remind republicans that they are on a very shaky mandate. Over half the country does not agree with Walker's agenda. Standing strong for an agenda which does not represent the views of over half your constituents will cost you. Big I hope.
Funny he didn't mention Sam Brownback in his list of heroic governors.  After all Brownback should be at the head of the list for going all in on his tea party  bets.

I live in Madison. I would like to know why the Times is giving this incompetent charlatan space to spout his ideological claptrap. Wisconsin has one of the poorest economic and social records of any state over the past 8 years. The Republican legislature elected from extreme gerrymandered districts passes ALEC laws without even reading them. They have turned our state into a northern Mississippi. Their latest is an attempt to give bottled water companies the right to pump our aquifers dry. Walker and all his cohorts will be shown over time to be on the wrong side of history. And if he thinks I will give up protesting against him and Trump and the rest of this semi-fascistic crowd, he better think again.

Walker has been taking lessons from Trump. He says, "...today the budget is balanced, taxes are down and more people in the state are working than ever," but the guys who deal in facts report that the Wisconsin economy is well below average in job creation and overall economic activity.

Who you gonna believe, Scott Walker, or your own lying eyes?

Some context for Mr Walker's bragging about Wisconsin's economic performance - this from the Milwaukee Journal Sentinel in September 2016

"Wisconsin continued to trail the nation, as it has since July 2011. The United States created private-sector jobs at a rate of 2.1% in the latest 12-month period, according to the data released Wednesday by the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics. Wisconsin ranked fourth among its Midwest peers, ahead of Minnesota, Illinois and Iowa, but behind Michigan, Indiana and Ohio.

Wednesday's lackluster report was on par for the state. Wisconsin's ranking was unchanged from a revised rank of 33rd in the previous jobs Census released three months earlier, which covered the 12 months of 2015, when Wisconsin also added private-sector jobs at a rate of 1.6%."
After doing extensive Googling, I'm unaware that Wisconsin is "doing well." Says who?

If local control is always better than federal, why stop at the level of the state? Don't cities know what they need more than the state knows? But don't individual neighborhood precincts know what they need better than the city knows? And aren't individual families really best positioned to determine how every single dollar they earn should be spent? Don't let your neighborhood try to take your hard-earned dollars and waste them on paving streets on which you never drive!

Walker's doctrine can be reduced to an anarchical, every-man-for-himself version of the wild west.

The opposing argument, which democrats/liberals seem to be learning to make, is that we function better when we work together. Ultimately, let's hope that this becomes a battle of ideas, because the idea of going it together is just much better than the idea of going it alone. Which is exactly why the Governor needs to publish an op-ed putting down the protesters. Liberals need to keep protesting the IDEAS coming from Washington (repugnant as the people in the new government may be).
if we're returning power to the people, why not abolish the states altogether and have local citizen councils?
